metadata.synopsis: A musical in which a modern day Romeo and Juliet are involved in New York street gangs. On the harsh streets of the upper west side, two gangs battle for control of the turf. The situation becomes complicated when a gang members falls in love with a rival's sister.

reviews: West Side Story grows on the viewer. It is that kind of motion picture that will want to be seen again and again.

Music, as only a gifted Leonard Bernstein can compose it, dominates the film. An enticing, tantalizing, mesmerizing pattern of melody holds the story together like a maestro a highly trained philharmonic.
The whole thing crackles and explodes with vitality, yet it remains a vitality subject to the beat of a conductor's baton, vitality disciplined and controlled to produce the maximum effect.
Among celebrated films, West Side Story is a rarity: it actually lives up to all the ballyhoo.
Will principally always be remembered for its music.
The real standout is the dancing and the songs

It is only fair to add that the technical credits, as they say, are all impeccable and the performances good enough within the limits laid down for them... But to cancel out the indecision at the film's centre, these are just not enough.
A radiant and touching performance by Natalie Wood as a Puerto Rican beauty in a New York slum is only one of the many strong points of this superb musical drama...
Jerome Robbins' choreography was as good as the critics said it was, but I was bothered by its unresolved discord with the "real" story.
Robert Wise hits the mark in creating an interesting and dramatic environment, with ordinary observations about immigrants. [Full Review in Spanish]
For the superlative-minded, West Side Story is the most expensive musical film ever made. It's also one of the best.
Both Miss Wood and Miss Moreno are permitted to work up fine fervors in their acting, and they come through.
Natalie Wood, who was made a hit in the Kazan-Inge production of Splendor In the Grass and is the most promising young star of today, gives a fine dramatic performance.

Ten well-deserved Oscars -- plus a special award for Jerome Robbins's dynamic choreography -- adorned this electrifying and moving version of the magnificent Leonard Bernstein/Stephen Sondheim musical.
for all of its silliness for today, is still an epic film

West Side Story is a beautifully-mounted, impressive, emotion-ridden and violent musical which, in its stark approach to a raging social problem and realism of unfoldment, may set a pattern for future musical presentations.
[VIDEO ESSAY] Indisputably the greatest musical ever made, "West Side Story" (1961) has sadly proven socially timeless regarding America's eternally troubled immigrant experience.
Even though I had to play it for my high school choir, I was never a fan of the music. Everything else - the cinematography, choreography and story are all pretty stellar.
You have to admire the way every aspect of the film works toward the emotional impact.
West Side Story remains one of the best musicals of all-time.
